title: Thanjavur Painting
summary: Thanjavur painting is a classical South Indian painting style originating from Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu. Its roots trace back to approximately 1600 AD under the Nayakas, though the style as known today developed in the Maratha court (1676–1855). Characterized by rich, vivid colors, iconic compositions, extensive gesso work, glittering gold foils, and inlay of glass beads or gems, it reflects influences from Deccani, Vijayanagara, Maratha, and European styles. Primarily depicting Hindu gods, goddesses, and saints as devotional icons, it also features subjects from Puranas, Sthala-puranas, and occasionally other religious or secular themes. These panel paintings, known as 'palagai padam', are now popular souvenirs in South India and received Geographical Indication status in 2007–08.

1676–1855: The art form, as known today, originated and flourished in the Maratha court of Thanjavur.
2007–08: Thanjavur painting was recognized as a Geographical Indication by the Government of India.

Souvenirs for festive occasions in South India.

current_status: Thanjavur painting is a recognized classical South Indian art form, holding Geographical Indication status. It is actively produced and popular as a cultural souvenir, particularly during festive occasions in South India.
future_prospects: The Geographical Indication status is likely to enhance its global recognition and market. Continued demand for cultural souvenirs and devotional art suggests ongoing production and artistic development. Efforts may focus on preserving traditional techniques while potentially exploring contemporary applications or broader exhibition opportunities.
